description: Probably from colic (“severe pains that grip the abdomen”) + wobble (“unsteady motion”). Alternatively, it has been suggested that the word derives from colly (“coal dust”) (in the sense of someone becoming ill from breathing in such dust), or that it is a corruption of cholera.

nouns.description: collywobbles pl (plural only) (Britain, informal, chiefly humorous)

entries.meaning: Often preceded by the: a stomach ache or an upset stomach. [from 1823]
examples: Petunia’s off school today with a touch of the collywobbles.

entries.meaning: (by extension) Often preceded by the: anxiety, fear, uneasiness.
examples: Synonyms: butterflies, butterflies in one’s stomach, creeps, heebie-jeebies, willies
I don’t like walking through the forest at night. It gives me the collywobbles.
